title: On 3 January 2019, how many U.S. senators will be women?
preds: No reason to think that Congress will not reconvene on January 3rd, especially with the continuing shutdown.

There has been no progress with the budget, so chances are higher that it won't be resolved by the third. https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-claims-without-evidence-that-most-of-the-people-not-getting-paid-in-partial-government-shutdown-are-democrats/2018/12/27/afbc992a-09cc-11e9-88e3-989a3e456820_story.html

The only time a shutdown has occurred at this time of the year, from what I can find, was '95-96.  They convened on time that year.  Being that it is a sample size of one, I will average it with the 40% on time rate over the past 20 years. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_shutdowns_in_the_United_States

If the shutdown is not resolved, I don't see how Congress doesn't start on January 3rd. If the shutdown is resolved quickly, I think they convene on the 3rd. If they resolved the shutdown in late December, maybe they push back the date of when congress reconvenes?  I also had a thought that maybe if a new party takes the majority, it is customary to let that party decide when congress starts, and I don't think Democrats are interested in a delay.

Ducey said Sinema will be sworn in first on Jan. 3, giving her not just the title of being the state’s senior senator but also the bragging rights of being Arizona’s first female senator. That decision was arranged at Ducey’s direction, his office said. McSally will be sworn in later on Jan. 3
Going to 25 because McSally has been appointed to the senate.

Ducey is appointing McSally, but with the limit that she begins in a way that gives Sinema seniority, so she will not be sworn in as soon as Kyl steps down. This makes it 23 (congress is postponed) or 25 (congress starts on time). 24 is still possible should someone leave the Senate. It'd be nice if you could do half percentage point increments.
McSally had been selected. Still sticking with a 60% chance they don't start on time.

I think the remaining big variable is if the the shutdown (if it happens and for how long) causes congress to postpone the start of the new session. I need to figure out how to not over-second guess myself based on random news after doing my initial research.
yup time for a new forecast.
McSally appointment news all over Twitter.

Realization: I think Senator Kyl's resignation timing means any pick would be considered part of the 115th Congress. This is why his replacement would have greater seniority. Appointments follow different rules for when they become officially Senators.  I've seen some additional names thrown around which makes me reduce 25+. Another line of thought I've seen is Ducey might have ambitions to run, and might want a lesser candidate he think he can beat. I don't know if that means he would run in 2 years or serve out the rest of his term.  He might think that no Republican candidate has a good shot 2 years from now as long as Republicans control the White House. Ticket-splitting was a big factor in Arizona when you compare margins of the gov and senate races.

Updating based on a point made by @Raahul_Kumar, Congress doesn't always start on time. In the past 20 years, it has only started on time 8 times, so I'm giving 60% for 23 and multiplying my previous 24 and 25-or-more predictions by 0.4.
Today I read a list of 5 rumored candidates:  only 1 was a male.
I believe McSally is the appointment and she'll be sworn in on day one of the Senate on January 3. Leaving 10 % in case Ducey decides to be more maverick....doubt it, but hoping I'm wrong.

"First of all, I would recommend Martha McSally for a lot of different things, including U.S. Senate, because I supported her candidacy," Kyl said. "But no, I've not made any decisions about when I'm going to step down." Kyl added that he would first consult with newly-reelected Gov. Doug Ducey (R-Ariz.) "and you all will be notified after that." https://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/op-ed/ej-montini/2018/11/14/jon-kyl-doug-ducey-senate-john-mccain/1997253002/ "Gov. Doug Ducey needs to convince Sen. Jon Kyl to stay on the job until 2020 and not step down in January, as Kyl hinted at doing when first appointed to fill the seat of the late Sen. John McCain. The one-word reason? Water. The man knows water..... Arizona is on the verge of a water crisis. Currently, Arizona, Nevada and Colorado are working on what is called the Lower Basin Drought Contingency Plan. The Colorado River produces less water than Arizona and other states are entitled to use. And that is a big problem for our drinking water. Water policy is really complicated. That’s why you didn’t hear Gov. Doug Ducey or his opponent, David Garcia, talking about it. As Nick Fouriezos of McClatchy wrote in an article recently, “Water becomes an issue not of partisan belief, but of competency.” And he added, “For nearly two decades, Jon Kyl, a former Arizona water attorney, served as guardian of the state’s water needs from his Senate perch …”"

Add Sinema = 24 
Add Blackburn = 25 
Add Rosen = 26 
Subtract Heitkamp and McCaskill = 24 Kyl is the wildcard that could increase it to 25 but that assumes Hyde Smith wins. If Hyde Smith loses and a woman replaces Kyl, it's 24.

I may have messed up on this one. I was 100% on 24. Kyl timeline to date and some relevant quotes; • 25 Aug 2018: John McCain dies. The same day, Governor Ducey asks Kyl to be McCains successor.
• 26 Aug 2018: After discussing with his wife, Kyl agrees to finish out the year [1].
• 4 Sept 2018: Ducey announces Kyl's appointment at a press conference in Phoenix [2]. Kyl says "The governor asked me to serve for the remainder of the term and he made some very convincing points. I have committed to serving at least through the second session of the 115th congress. I do know I will not seek this seat in 2020 nor any other office in the future." He expands further in response to questions from reporters.
• 5 Sept 2018: Kyl takes the oath of office in the Senate [3].
• 13 Nov 2018: According to CNN, Kyl has made his decision but won't disclose what it is [4]. Future events; • 14 Dec 2018: Current senatorial session ends.
• 3 Jan 2019: 116th Congress begins. This question closes. So it's pretty clear that Kyl only intended to serve until the end of the year, although Ducey wants him to continue until the end of 2019. If he does quit, it makes sense for his replacement to be sworn in with the other candidates on 3 Jan 2019. A simulation (see code below) assuming that all elections are independent gives the following result 19 or fewer: 0%
20: 0%
21: 1%
22: 8%
23: 26%
24: 37%
25 or more: 28% However  @Prognosticating-Beek has an interesting way of getting some dependency into the calculation. You could indeed say that when e.g. Heidi Heitkamp should win, that this would indeed indicate a “wave” and that other candidates like McCaskill and Rosen would be lifted up! I have redone the calculation with this premise and then the results are: 19 or fewer: 0%
20: 0%
21: 1%
22: 7%
23: 23%
24: 31%
25 or more: 38% This shifts the end total towards the higher numbers. I would suggest taken the mean of these calculations. After rounding and making sure that the sum is 100% I suggest: 19 or fewer: 0%
20: 0%
21: 1%
22: 7%
23: 25%
24: 34%
25 or more: 33% The R-code (I keep it in "human readable format"; make sure to load library "Tidyverse") is: set.seed(2018)
# number of simulated elections
N <- 10000
# probability of a win for Democratic female candidate vs a Republican man
pCal <- 0.99
pHaw <- 0.99
pMass <- 0.99
pMich <- 0.99
pMinn <- 0.99
pMissi <- 0.83
pMisso <- 0.55
pND <- 0.3
pNeva <- 0.47
pTenn <- 0.8
# simulation of the N elections using a binomial distribution
XCal <- rbinom(N, size=1, prob=pCal)
XHaw <- rbinom(N, size=1, prob=pHaw)
XMass <- rbinom(N, size=1, prob=pMass)
XMich <- rbinom(N, size=1, prob=pMich)
XMinn <- rbinom(N, size=1, prob=pMinn)
XMissi <- rbinom(N, size=1, prob=pMissi)
XMisso <- rbinom(N, size=1, prob=pMisso)
XND <- rbinom(N, size=1, prob=pND)
XNeva <- rbinom(N, size=1, prob=pNeva)
XTenn <- rbinom(N, size=1, prob=pTenn)
# assuming that all election results are independent of each other
Y <- XCal + XHaw + XMass + XMich + XMinn + XMissi + XMisso + XND + XNeva + XTenn
elec.ind <- data.frame(Cal=XCal, Haw=XHaw, Mass=XMass, Mich=XMich, Minn=XMinn, Missi=XMissi, Misso=XMisso, ND=XND, Neva=XNeva, Tenn=XTenn, tot=Y)
ggplot(data=elec.ind, aes(tot)) + geom_histogram(binwidth=0.5)
elec.ind %>% count(tot) %>% mutate(perc=100*n/N)
# assuming some dependency: if Heidi Heidkamp wins, than this will lead to a win of McCaskill and Rosen
elec.dep <- elec.ind
for (i in 1:N) {
  if(elec.dep$ND[i] == 1) {
    elec.dep$Misso[i] <- 1
    elec.dep$Tenn[i] <- 1
  }
}
elec.dep$tot <- elec.dep$Cal + elec.dep$Haw + elec.dep$Mass + elec.dep$Mich + elec.dep$Minn + elec.dep$Missi + elec.dep$Misso + elec.dep$ND + elec.dep$Neva + elec.dep$Tenn
ggplot(data=elec.dep, aes(tot)) + geom_histogram(binwidth=0.5)
elec.dep %>% count(tot) %>% mutate(perc=100*n/N)

There seem to be five competitive races: # Heitkamp - Democrat
# McCaskill - Democrat
# Hyde-Smith - Republican
# Rosen - Democrat
# Blackburn - Republican ... and X number of "safe" Senator seats to be held by women. It seems like from @Prognosticating-Beek's analysis he is assuming that X = 20, but @JMR2017/@Anneinak suggests that it's actually 21. This is quite an important assumption. For now, I assume 21.  I built a Monte Carlo model that takes into account dependence in outcomes. As discussed with @ttltran and Beek, I incorporate a "Partisan Advantage" variable: this is a random variable that takes on a value around 0 with a standard deviation of 10 percentage points. I take a positive value to reflect a D advantage and vice versa and I add this random variable to the 538 chances of D competitive women and subtract it from the 538 caches of R competitive women. Then, the outcome of each competitive race is determined by a random pick loaded on the basis of the aforementioned calculated probabilities for each race. Then my model repeats this 50,000 times and calculates frequencies.  Interestingly, the addition of the Party Advantage variable doesn't seem to change the results significantly based on sensitivity analysis I did by turning it on and off. I attribute this to the fact that 2 of the 5 women in competitive races are Republican meaning that there is actual anti-correlation between these races and the D races in my model. This is all based on the assumption that the relationship between women winning races is all based on partisanship, i.e. whether there is a blue wave or red wave. In reality, things will be a bit more complicated. I.e. there is probably correlation between outcomes based on type of voters (suburban vs. rural) or correlation due to #metoo turnout. I am guessing that my model is erring on the side of too little overall correlation by assuming too much anti-correlation between a D woman and an R woman. For this reason, I am upping the odds of higher numbers slightly. Python code: from numpy import random # Odds data (538 with Kavanaguh adjustment for Heitkamp)
ND = 0.20 # Heitkamp - Democrat
MO = 0.55 # McCaskill - Democrat
MS = 0.83 # Hyde-Smith - Republican
NV = 0.43 # Rosen - Democrat
TN = 0.78 # Blackburn - Republican # Model outcome dependence through a "Party Advantage" variable. # Define parameters for the distribution of the Party Advantage std_party_adv = 0.1 # arbitrary, taken as something that seems reasonable
party_adv = 0 # we are varying the party advantage around 0. This is done becauses 538 odds below already reflect generic ballot differences. # Function to estimate number of women to win competitive races
def election():     # Odds data (538 with Kavanaguh adjustment for Heitkamp)
    ND = 0.20 # Heitkamp - Democrat
    MO = 0.55 # McCaskill - Democrat
    MS = 0.83 # Hyde-Smith - Republican
    NV = 0.43 # Rosen - Democrat
    TN = 0.78 # Blackburn - Republican     # Sample Party Advantage
    party_advantage = np.random.normal(loc = party_adv, scale = std_party_adv)     # adjust party advantage - this allows me to explicitly control the interdependence b/n outcomes
    party_advantage *= 1     # Add party advantage to odds depending on Democrat or Republican, lazy way     ND += party_advantage
    MO += party_advantage
    MS -= party_advantage
    NV += party_advantage
    TN -= party_advantage     competitive_races=[ND,MO,MS,NV,TN]
    sum = 0
    for race in competitive_races:
        # Estimate sum of competitive race women to win
        sum += random.choice([1, 0], p=[min(1,max(0,race)), 1-min(1,max(0,race))])
    return(sum) # Monte Carlo
iterations = 50000
results=[]
iter = 0
while iter < iterations:
    results.append(election())
    iter += 1 # Add safe senators
safe_senators = 21
results = [i+safe_senators for i in results] # Results
set(results) # Collect results in table
collect_results = pd.DataFrame(0,index=set(results),columns=['Probability'])
for i in set(results):
    collect_results.loc[i] = results.count(i)/len(results) collect_results.sum() # sanity check
collect_results

Updating based on today's https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/?ex_cid=rrpromo and repeating much of my earlier rationale for convenience Currently there are 23 women in the Senate, out of whom 13 are running for reelection. Of those 13, five (Nebraska, New York, Wisconsin, Minnesota and Washington) have women standing from both main parties, which leaves eight. These are Missouri, North Dakota, Michigan, California, Minnesota, Mississippi, Hawaii and Massachusetts. According to 538 today, their chances are 
North Dakota (Heitkamp) 33% 
Missouri (McCaskill 57%) 
Mississippi (Hyde-Smith) 83% 
Michigan (Stabenow) >99% 
California (Feinstein) 99% 
MInnesota (Klobuchar)>99% 
Hawaii (Hirono) >99% 
Massachusetts (Warren) >99% So Heitkamp looks like losing, and it's more likely than not that one of McCaskill and Hyde-Smith will lose too. On the other hand there will be an additional woman Senator from Arizona replacing a male, as both main candidates are women. Finally, Jacky Rosen is running against Dean Heller in Nevada, and 538 has her at 48% today, while Marsha Blackburn has an 80% chance against a male in Tennessee.  At least one of these two should win. (There's also long shot Jenny Wilson (<1% per 538) against Mitt Romney in Utah but one can ignore that race).  Summarizing the above, ten women are not up for reelection this year and six elections have a guaranteed woman winner. Five more women are practically certain (98% chance that all five win), so that makes 21.  Another five have chances of 33,48,57, 80 and 83% respectively) so one can expect three out of five to win. Thus, the most likely outcome is that the number of women in the Senate increases from 23 to 24 after all the elections including Mississippi are completed.

First, a shoutout to @Kahlid and @ttltran , they did a good starting analysis here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/780225  and https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/740671 However, it is time to take it over the finish line. It is time for a visit by Mr. Monte Carlo himself.  
To be fair, I had to add in a 1 in 1000 chance independent female candidate vying for a senate seat against 2 main party men. Because their really is a 1 in 1000 chance she could win and we're about to run the election 10,000,000 times over and over.   For those who don't know what Monte Carlo is, I give you https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_method  Which essentially is a statistical technique of doing a Groundhog Day thing, but with the election over and over a gazillion times. The result was surprising, and if some other R coder spots an error, please let me know.  The Histogram plot is here:  http://pc.cd/Wof7
I haven't done a Monte Carlo analysis in ages, so if you are an R user, examine my code closely for errors.  The most likely error will be forgetting a race, or adding in a race twice. By bucket results were:
> sum(x <= 19 )/length(random_numbers)
[1] 0.0130118
> sum(x == 20 )/length(random_numbers)
[1] 0.1550062
> sum(x == 21 )/length(random_numbers)

> sum(x == 22 )/length(random_numbers)
[1] 0.2429659
> sum(x == 23 )/length(random_numbers)
[1] 0.0899514
> sum(x == 24 )/length(random_numbers)
[1] 0.1450977
> sum(x >= 25 )/length(random_numbers)
[1] 0.3249168 I chose to round '20 bucket' up and '19 bucket' down to 0. @dsarin @Dima @shivadiva @nigster Here is my R code below

random_numbers<-sample(1:1000, size = 10000000, replace = TRUE)
for (i in 1:length(random_numbers)){
x[i]<-0  # initialize
Heitkamp <- random_numbers[i]
McCaskill <- random_numbers[i]
Hyde_Smith <- random_numbers[i]
Stabenow  <- random_numbers[i]
Feinstein <- random_numbers[i]

I wasn't going to do this but since there's a Tee Shirt lottery..... Currently there are 23 women in the Senate, out of whom 13 are running for reelection. Of those 13, five (Nebraska, New York, Wisconsin, Minnesota and Washington) have women candidates from both main parties, which leaves eight.  These are Missouri, North Dakota, Michigan, California, Minnesota, Mississippi, Hawaii and Massachusetts. According to 538 today, their chances are
North Dakota (Heitkamp) 30%
Missouri (McCaskill 55%)
Mississippi (Hyde-Smith) 83%
Michigan (Stabenow) >99%
California (Feinstein) >99%
MInnesota (Klobuchar)>99%
Hawaii (Hirono) >99%
Massachusetts (Warren) >99% So Heitkamp looks like losing, and it's more likely than not that one of McCaskill and Hyde-Smith will lose too. On the other hand there will be an additional woman Senator from Arizona replacing a male, as both main candidates are women.   Finally, Jacky Rosen is running against Dean Heller in Nevada, and 538 has her at 47% today, while Marsha Blackburn has an 80% chance against a male in Tennessee (There's also long shot Jenny Wilson (<1% per 538) against Mitt Romney  in Utah but one can ignore that race). At least one of these two should win. Summarizing the above,  ten women are not up for reelection this year and six elections have a guaranteed woman winner. Five more women are practically certain (>99% chances), so that makes 21. Another five have chances of 30,47,55, 80 and 83% respectively) so one can expect three out of five to win.  Thus, the most likely outcomes are that the number of women in the Senate remains at 23 or becomes 24 after all the elections including Mississippi are completed. There are 22 women running in Senate contests this year, up from the previous record of 18 in 2012. Eleven of those women are favoured to win — including the six contests where a woman is running against a woman, also a record. But if women win all the competitive races — this includes two Democratic incumbents, Claire McCaskill of Missouri and Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota — there will be 25 women in the Senate, a slight increase but also a record-breaking one.

Adjusting previous forecast because of Greitens resignation: https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/campaigns/republicans-eric-greitens-resignation-huge-monkey-off-our-back-in-race-against-claire-mccaskill ______________ "The resignation of embattled Missouri Republican Gov. Eric Greitens should cement Democratic Sen. Claire McCaskill’s defeat in the midterm elections, Republicans confidently predicted on Wednesday. Multiple scandals plaguing Greitens since January threatened to derail the Senate bid of Missouri Attorney General Josh Hawley, the presumed GOP nominee. But with Greitens sidelined — his resignation takes effect Friday — Republicans expect the Senate campaign to become a referendum on McCaskill, to their advantage in a state where a majority approve of President Trump. “It’s a huge monkey off our back,” a senior Republican strategist in Washington said. “McCaskill’s clearly the loser in the current scenario,” added Gregg Keller, a Republican consultant based in Missouri who had sounded the alarm about the harm Greitens could do to Hawley’s Senate campaign. “With the Greitens debacle behind him, Josh now has every opportunity to win the seat and hold the Senate for Republicans.” Greitens announced late Tuesday that he would resign June 1 after spending the five months defending himself against allegations of sexual misconduct and mismanagement of a charity. Charges against the governor, a political outsider first elected in 2016, appeared to mount as he resisted calls from within his own party to step down or face impeachment by a Republican legislature. The soap opera proved a lifeline to McCaskill. The vulnerable Democrat, in trouble for her liberal voting record and opposition of Trump’s agenda, was buffered as Hawley’s campaign was hampered by the Greitens affair. Hawley, in his capacity as state attorney general, was involved in investigating the governor, an effort that angered the GOP base on the one hand and was deemed unsatisfactory by the broader electorate on the other. Democrats involved in the Senate contest claim the issue will linger as a problem for Hawley long after Greitens exits the scene, even though he previously called on the governor to resign and said in a statement that “Gov. Greitens has done the right thing” in finally doing so. “They may think the immediate pressure has been relieved,” a Democratic Senate campaign aide said in an email. “But Hawley’s vulnerabilities on this scandal remain: he took $50,000 from Greitens — which he still hasn’t returned — then looked the other way for a year until he ran a ‘widely mocked,’ ‘sub-standard’ investigation of the governor.” Wishful thinking, retort Republicans who have for months openly fretted that Greitens would tank an otherwise sure-thing Senate race for the GOP. It wouldn’t be the first time McCaskill got lucky. In 2012, she appeared just as politically endangered, but won a second term after then-Rep. Todd Akin, the unlikely GOP nominee, made offensive statements about rape. McCaskill is running competitively with Hawley in recent public opinion polls; she held a 45 percent to 43.3 percent lead in the RealClearPolitics average. But the Democrat’s personal standing in a state that approves of Trump by 50 percent is falling short of her position in the horse race, suggesting trouble ahead. According to Morning Consult data that surveyed nearly 300,000 registered voters across the country from Jan. 1–April 30, Missouri voters gave McCaskill a paltry 38 percent approval rating. These numbers, combined with what some Republicans are describing as a newly aggressive Hawley after initial criticism for how he was running his campaign, are problematic for McCaskill without the Greitens scandal to offset her inherent political weakness. Republican insiders said McCaskill might have mitigated her challenges by syncing herself with the politics of her state through support of a few prominent items on Trump’s legislative agenda, or high profile nominees, whether Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch or just-confirmed Central Intelligence Agency Director Gina Haspel. “Claire’s path to re-election has always been to get a lot of Trump voters. To do that she had to support a lot of the Trump agenda. She refused. It was probably a career-ending mistake,” a Republican strategist said." _______________ Comments: While McCaskill does have a track record of performing well in tough elections, whether because of luck or skill, I don't know, even with the "blue wave" coming in, if she can withstand Hawley.

22.1% of 2018 congressional candidates are female
Gender has been a prevailing theme of national and local media coverage in this year’s elections. We took a look at our data on the nearly 3,000 Congressional candidates in our database. Ballotpedia has tracked 2,945 candidates who are seeking or sought election to Congress in 2018. A total of 651 (22.1%) of these candidates are female and 2,294 (77.9%) are male. Five more facts about congressional gender data: Approximately 30.5% of Democratic congressional candidates are female 14.1% of Republican congressional candidates are female. The state with the fewest female candidates is Rhode Island, which currently does not have any declared female candidates. California has the highest number of declared female candidates, with 86. However, Hawaii has the highest percentage of female candidates to total candidates, with 42.9% of 14 declared candidates being female.

Of the 23 female senators, 13 are up for reelection in 2018 (11 normal cycle and 2 special elections). As @Pixolet noted, the 3 most likely to lose their seats are McCaskill, Heitkamp, and Baldwin. As the primaries continue to shake out, we'll get a better idea of who the main candidates for both parties will be for some other seats. Of states that can be won by women candidates, Arizona, Nevada, and Tennessee are the most likely (in my opinion and that of @Pixolet below) of having a female senator in January 2019.  I think McCaskill is the only one truly in danger, and I think Arizona is the most likely to gain a female senator. What I am less sure of, and will rely on the primaries to assist with, is whether any male incumbents (R or D) fall to women challengers, especially in blue states that are shifting more towards the Bernie Sanders wing of the party. However, initial research indicates those incumbents are likely safe for this election cycle. So, most likely, 23 female senators in January 2019, with a possible +/-1 (slight edge to +1).

According to The Hill (http://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/382579-the-10-senate-seats-most-likely-to-flip-in-2018), 3 of the seats most likely to flip in this year's midterms are:  1. Claire McCaskill (D Mo.): "McCaskill has always faced a tough road to reelection. She’s one of just three Democrats elected statewide in Missouri, which Trump won by almost 20 points. And the GOP is already seizing on McCaskill’s ardent support for Clinton in 2016 as a way to rile up the base. Still, she’s won a reputation as a strong campaigner and a consistently prolific fundraiser this cycle. State Attorney General Josh Hawley is still considered a top GOP recruit. But Republicans are closely watching his first-quarter fundraising haul following grumblings about his disappointing fundraising pace last year. The investigations into blackmail allegations against Missouri Gov. Eric Greitens (R) could add a tinge of scandal to the Republican brand in the state." Also, GJO gives her a 65% chance of reelection, so I gotta take that into account :) 2. Heidi Heitkamp (D N.D): "Republicans caught a break when they convinced Rep. Kevin Cramer to mount a late bid against Heitkamp. Cramer has made his campaign about fierce loyalty to Trump, who won the state by 36 points in 2016. Cramer can also run on the statewide name recognition he’s built up as a three-term congressman in an at-large seat. But Republicans had wavered on Cramer before, looking for other alternatives to the gaffe-prone congressman before ultimately settling on him as the top choice. And while Trump repeatedly pushed Cramer to run, the president has also been on good terms with Heitkamp, who has appeared on stage with him in North Dakota and flew on Air Force One. The escalating trade war between Trump and China could also dampen the GOP’s prospects. China’s retaliatory tariffs threaten to hurt jobs in the agriculture-heavy state, an issue that could weigh on Cramer." 3. Tammy Baldwin (D Wis.): "Wisconsin was once seen as a reach for Republicans. But the barrage of attack ads from outside GOP groups have softened Baldwin up ahead of November, prompting a flurry of Democratic spending meant to shore up the senator. It’s still unclear who will emerge from the contentious GOP primary. Marine Corps veteran Kevin Nicholson, a former Democrat, is the pick of top conservative groups, but state Sen. Leah Vukmir has some big Wisconsin names in her corner." Both McCaskill and Heitkamp are being challenged by men, but both races are pretty much tossups at this point. However, Leah Vukmir has the backing of the state GOP organization (https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2018/05/23/state-republican-party-going-all-leah-vukmir-wisconsin-u-s-senate-race/634291002/), so if Vukmir is elected, then that seat will not change per this forecast. However, there is another factor that must be considered. That is, the empty Arizona Senate seat left by Jeff Flake. The leaders from both parties, Kyrsten Sinema and Martha McSally, are women, so I would give a +1 for women senators. *Side note, McSally's main competition in the GOP primary is another woman, Kelli Ward. In addition, the race to replace Sen. Bob Corker (Tennessee) is looking very close between Phil Bredesen, the Democratic candidate, and Marsha Blackburn, that of the GOP, but Bredesen looks to have a slight lead in polls. Finally, there are the men who will be challenged by women (I'm only going to include the ones that look to be close). So far, these are: 1. Dean Heller (R NV.): "Heller is the only Republican incumbent defending a seat in a state Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton won in 2016 — bad news for him as Democratic enthusiasm surges. His opponent, Rep. Jacky Rosen (D), has posted strong fundraising numbers and is trying to press Heller for his waffling on the GOP health-care repeal and his public role in crafting the GOP tax bill."  Apparently, this race is a tossup, but according to RealClearPolitics, it "could quickly shift to Lean D status."
